members.member: @author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)
This method is called after the node has been made the current node. It indicates that child nodes can now be added to it.
This method is called after all the child nodes have been added.
This pair of methods are used to inform the node of its parent.
This method tells the node to add its argument to the node's list of children.
This method returns a child node. The children are numbered from zero, left to right.
Return the number of children the node has.
Extracts the value from the given source object that is appropriate for this node within the given context.
Sets the given value in the given target as appropriate for this node within the given context.
Subclasses implement this method to do the actual work of extracting the appropriate value from the source object.

Subclasses implement this method to do the actual work of setting the appropriate value in the target object. The default implementation // throws an InappropriateExpressionException, meaning that it cannot be a set expression.
Returns true iff this node is constant without respect to the children.

This method may be called from subclasses' jjtClose methods. It flattens the tree under this node by eliminating any children that are of the same class as this node and copying their children to this node.
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)
Returns true iff this node is constant without respect to the children.
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)

members.member: Constructs a new OgnlContext with the default class resolver, type converter and member access.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlContext.#ctor(ognl.ClassResolver,ognl.TypeConverter,ognl.MemberAccess)
member.summary: Constructs a new OgnlContext with the given class resolver, type converter and member access. If any of these parameters is null the default will be used.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlContext.recycleLastEvaluation
member.summary: This method can be called when the last evaluation has been used and can be returned for reuse in the free pool maintained by the runtime. This is not a necessary step, but is useful for keeping memory usage down. This will recycle the last evaluation and then set the last evaluation to null.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlContext.getKeepLastEvaluation
member.summary: Returns true if the last evaluation that was done on this context is retained and available through getLastEvaluation(). The default is true.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlContext.setKeepLastEvaluation(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets whether the last evaluation that was done on this context is retained and available through getLastEvaluation(). The default is true.

members.member: Gets the current Evaluation from the top of the stack. This is the Evaluation that is in process of evaluating.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlContext.getRootEvaluation
member.summary: Gets the root of the evaluation stack. This Evaluation contains the node representing the root expression and the source is the root source object.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlContext.getEvaluation(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the Evaluation at the relative index given. This should be zero or a negative number as a relative reference back up the evaluation stack. Therefore getEvaluation(0) returns the current Evaluation.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlContext.pushEvaluation(ognl.Evaluation)
member.summary: Pushes a new Evaluation onto the stack. This is done before a node evaluates. When evaluation is complete it should be popped from the stack via popEvaluation().

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlContext.popEvaluation
member.summary: Pops the current Evaluation off of the top of the stack. This is done after a node has completed its evaluation.

members.member: Lexical error occured.
Tried to change to an invalid lexical state.
Indicates the reason why the exception is thrown. It will have one of the above 4 values.
Replaces unprintable characters by their espaced (or unicode escaped) equivalents in the given string

Returns a detailed message for the Error when it is thrown by the token manager to indicate a lexical error. Parameters : EOFSeen : indicates if EOF caused the lexicl error curLexState : lexical state in which this error occured errorLine : line number when the error occured errorColumn : column number when the error occured errorAfter : prefix that was seen before this error occured curchar : the offending character Note: You can customize the lexical error message by modifying this method.

You can also modify the body of this method to customize your error messages. For example, cases like LOOP_DETECTED and INVALID_LEXICAL_STATE are not of end-users concern, so you can return something like :
"Internal Error : Please file a bug report .... "
from this method for such cases in the release version of your parser.
Holds the last value computed by a constant token.
Holds the last character escaped or in a character literal.
Holds the last string literal parsed.
Converts an escape sequence into a character value.
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)
Returns an Evaluation that contains the node, source and whether it is a set operation. If there are no Evaluation objects in the pool one is created and returned.
Returns an Evaluation that contains the node, source and whether it is a set operation. If there are no Evaluation objects in the pool one is created and returned.
Recycles an Evaluation
Recycles an of Evaluation and all of it's siblings and children.
Recycles a List of Evaluation objects
Returns the number of items in the pool
Returns the number of items this pool has created since it's construction.
Returns the number of items this pool has recovered from the pool since its construction.
Returns the number of items this pool has recycled since it's construction.

member.name: F:ognl.NumericTypes.NONNUMERIC
member.summary: Type tag meaning something other than a number.

member.name: F:ognl.NumericTypes.MIN_REAL_TYPE
member.summary: The smallest type tag that represents reals as opposed to integers. You can see whether a type tag represents reals or integers by comparing the tag to this constant: all tags less than this constant represent integers, and all tags greater than or equal to this constant represent reals. Of course, you must also check for NONNUMERIC, which means it is not a number at all.

member.name: T:ognl.Evaluation
member.summary: An Evaluation is and object that holds a node being evaluated and the source from which that node will take extract its value.
member.remarks: It refers to child evaluations that occur as a result of the nodes' evaluation.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.#ctor(ognl.SimpleNode,System.Object)
member.summary: Constructs a new "get" Evaluation from the node and source given.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.#ctor(ognl.SimpleNode,System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a new Evaluation from the node and source given. If setOperation is true this Evaluation represents a "set" as opposed to a "get".

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getNode
member.summary: Returns the SimpleNode for this Evaluation

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.setNode(ognl.SimpleNode)
member.summary: Sets the node of the evaluation. Normally applications do not need to set this. Notable exceptions to this rule are custom evaluators that choose between navigable objects (as in a multi-root evaluator where the navigable node is chosen at runtime).

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getSource
member.summary: Returns the source object on which this Evaluation operated.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.setSource(System.Object)
member.summary: Sets the source of the evaluation. Normally applications do not need to set this. Notable exceptions to this rule are custom evaluators that choose between navigable objects (as in a multi-root evaluator where the navigable node is chosen at runtime).

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.isSetOperation
member.summary: Returns true if this Evaluation represents a set operation.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.setSetOperation(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Marks the Evaluation as a set operation if the value is true, else marks it as a get operation.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getResult
member.summary: Returns the result of the Evaluation, or null if it was a set operation.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.setResult(System.Object)
member.summary: Sets the result of the Evaluation. This method is normally only used interally and should not be set without knowledge of what you are doing.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getException
member.summary: Returns the exception that occurred as a result of evaluating the Evaluation, or null if no exception occurred.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.setException(System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets the exception that occurred as a result of evaluating the Evaluation. This method is normally only used interally and should not be set without knowledge of what you are doing.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getParent
member.summary: Returns the parent evaluation of this evaluation. If this returns null then it is is the root evaluation of a tree.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getNext
member.summary: Returns the next sibling of this evaluation. Returns null if this is the last in a chain of evaluations.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getPrevious
member.summary: Returns the previous sibling of this evaluation. Returns null if this is the first in a chain of evaluations.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getFirstChild
member.summary: Returns the first child of this evaluation. Returns null if there are no children.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getLastChild
member.summary: Returns the last child of this evaluation. Returns null if there are no children.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getFirstDescendant
member.summary: Gets the first descendent. In any Evaluation tree this will the Evaluation that was first executed.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.getLastDescendant
member.summary: Gets the last descendent. In any Evaluation tree this will the Evaluation that was most recently executing.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.addChild(ognl.Evaluation)
member.summary: Adds a child to the list of children of this evaluation. The parent of the child is set to the receiver and the children references are modified in the receiver to reflect the new child. The lastChild of the receiver is set to the child, and the firstChild is set also if child is the first (or only) child.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.init(ognl.SimpleNode,System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Reinitializes this Evaluation to the parameters specified.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.reset
member.summary: Resets this Evaluation to the initial state.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.ToString(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Produces a string value for the Evaluation. If compact is true then a more compact form of the description only including the node type and unique identifier is shown, else a full description including source and result are shown. If showChildren is true the child evaluations are printed using the depth string given as a prefix.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.ToString(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Produces a string value for the Evaluation. If compact is true then a more compact form of the description only including the node type and unique identifier is shown, else a full description including source and result are shown. Child evaluations are printed using the depth string given as a prefix.

member.name: M:ognl.Evaluation.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string description of the Evaluation.

members.member:
This interface defines methods for setting and getting a property from a target object. A "property" in this case is a named data value that takes the generic form of an object---the same definition as is used by beans. But the operational semantics of the term will vary by implementation of this interface: a bean-style implementation will get and set properties as beans do, by reflection on the target object's class, but other implementations are possible, such as one that uses the property name as a key into a map.
An implementation of this interface will often require that its target objects all be of some particular type. For example, the MapPropertyAccessor class requires that its targets all implement the java.util.IDictionary interface.
Note that the "name" of a property is represented by a generic object. Some implementations may require properties' names to be Strings, while others may allow them to be other types---for example, ArrayPropertyAccessor treats Number names as indexes into the target object, which must be an array.
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)

member.name: M:ognl.ObjectPropertyAccessor.getPossibleProperty(System.Collections.IDictionary,System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Returns OgnlRuntime.NotFound if the property does not exist.

member.name: M:ognl.ObjectPropertyAccessor.setPossibleProperty(System.Collections.IDictionary,System.Object,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns OgnlRuntime.NotFound if the property does not exist.

member.name: M:ognl.ArrayPropertyAccessor.getProperty(System.Collections.IDictionary,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Specific property is: length.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.compareWithConversion(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Compares two objects for equality, even if it has to convert one of them to the other type. If both objects are numeric they are converted to the widest type and compared.
member.remarks:
If one is non-numeric and one is numeric the non-numeric is converted to double and compared to the double numeric value.
If both are non-numeric and Comparable and the types are compatible (i.e. v1 is of the same or superclass of v2's type) they are compared with Comparable.compareTo(). If both values are non-numeric and not Comparable or of incompatible classes this will throw and IllegalArgumentException.
member.param: First value to compare
second value to compare
member.returns: integer describing the comparison between the two objects. A negative number indicates that v1 < v2. Positive indicates that v1 > v2. Zero indicates v1 == v2.
member.exception: if the objects are both non-numeric yet of incompatible types or do not implement Comparable.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.isEqual(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns true if object1 is equal to object2 in either the sense that they are the same object or, if both are non-null if they are equal in the Equals() sense.
member.param: First object to compare
Second object to compare
member.returns: true if object1 == object1

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.booleanValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Evaluates the given object as a bool: if it is a Boolean object, it's easy; if it's a Number or a Character, returns true for non-zero objects; and otherwise returns true for non-null objects.
member.param: an object to interpret as a bool
member.returns: the bool value implied by the given object

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.longValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Evaluates the given object as a long integer.
member.param: an object to interpret as a long integer
member.returns: the long integer value implied by the given object
member.exception: if the given object can't be understood as a long integer

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.doubleValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Evaluates the given object as a double-precision floating-point number.
member.param: an object to interpret as a double
member.returns: the double value implied by the given object
member.exception: if the give object can't be understood as a double

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.bigIntValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Evaluates the given object as a BigInteger.
member.param: an object to interpret as a BigInt
member.returns: the BigInt value implied by the given object
member.exception: if the give object can't be understood as a BigInt

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.bigDecValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Evaluates the given object as a BigDecimal.
member.param: an object to interpret as a BigDecimal
member.returns: the BigDecimal value implied by the given object
member.exception: if the give object can't be understood as a BigDecimal

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.stringValue(System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Evaluates the given object as a string and trims it if the trim flag is true.
member.param: an object to interpret as a string
member.returns: the string value implied by the given object as returned by the ToString() method, or "null" if the object is null.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.stringValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Evaluates the given object as a string.
member.param: an object to interpret as a string
member.returns: the string value implied by the given object as returned by the ToString() method, or "null" if the object is null.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.getNumericType(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a constant from the NumericTypes interface that represents the numeric type of the given object.
member.param: an object that needs to be interpreted as a number
member.returns: the appropriate constant from the NumericTypes interface

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.convertValue(System.Object,System.Type)
member.summary: Returns the value converted numerically to the given class type
member.remarks: This method also detects when arrays are being converted and converts the components of one array to the type of the other.
member.param: an object to be converted to the given type
class type to be converted to
member.returns: converted value of the type given, or value if the value cannot be converted to the given type.

member.name: M:ognl.OgnlOps.getNumericType(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the constant from the NumericTypes interface that best expresses the type of a numeric operation on the two given objects.
member.param: one argument to a numeric operator
the other argument
member.returns: the appropriate constant from the NumericTypes interface

Called from parser actions.

This interface defines a method for getting the "elements" of an object, which means any objects that naturally would be considered to be contained by the object. So for a collection, you would expect this method to return all the objects in that collection; while for an ordinary object you would expect this method to return just that object.
An implementation of this interface will often require that its target objects all be of some particular type.
For example, the class requires that its targets all implement the interface. * @author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) author: Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)

member.name: M:ognl.IElementsAccessor.getElements(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns an iterator over the elements of the given target object.
member.param: the object to get the elements of
member.returns: an iterator over the elements of the given object
member.exception: if there is an error getting the given object's elements

member.name: M:ognl.IteratorElementsAccessor.getElements(System.Object)
member.summary: There is no Iterator in C#, use IEnumerator instead.

member.name: M:ognl.ArrayElementsAccessor.getElements(System.Object)
member.summary: Just return Array.GetEnumerator.
member.param: The Array
member.returns: Enumerator

members.member: Token returned by TypeConverter for no conversion possible
Not an indexed property
JavaBeans IndexedProperty
OGNL ObjectIndexedProperty
Prefix padding for hexadecimal numbers to HEX_LENGTH.
Hexadecimal prefix for printing "pointers".
Returned by getUniqueDescriptor() when the object is null.

Gets the "target" class of an object for looking up accessors that are registered on the target. If the object is a Type object this will return the Type itself, else it will return object's GetType() result.
Returns the base name (the class name without the package name prepended) of the object given.
Returns the base name (the class name without the package name prepended) of the class given.
Returns the package name of the object's class.
Returns the package name of the class given.

Returns a unique descriptor string that includes the object's class and a unique integer identifier. If fullyQualified is true then the class name will be fully qualified to include the package name, else it will be just the class' base name.
Returns a unique descriptor string that includes the object's class' base name and a unique integer identifier.
Utility to convert a List into an object[] array. If the list is zero elements this will return a constant array; toArray() on List always returns a new object and this is wasteful for our purposes.
Returns the parameter types of the given method.
Returns the parameter types of the given method.

Tells whether the given object is compatible with the given class ---that is, whether the given object can be passed as an argument to a method or constructor whose parameter type is the given class. If object is null this will return true because null is compatible with any type.

Tells whether the given array of objects is compatible with the given array of classes---that is, whether the given array of objects can be passed as arguments to a method or constructor whose parameter types are the given array of classes.
Tells whether the first array of classes is more specific than the second. Assumes that the two arrays are of the same length.

Gets the appropriate method to be called for the given target, method name and arguments. If successful this method will return the Method within the target that can be called and the converted arguments in actualArgs. If unsuccessful this method will return null and the actualArgs will be empty.

If the checkAccessAndExistence flag is true this method will check to see if the method exists and if it is accessible according to the context's MemberAccess. If neither test passes this will return NotFound.
This method returns the property descriptors for the given class as a IDictionary
* TODO: About PropertyDescriptor This method returns a PropertyDescriptor for the given class and property name using a IDictionary lookup (using getPropertyDescriptorsMap()).

Determines the index property type, if any. Returns INDEXED_PROPERTY_NONE if the property is not index-accessible as determined by OGNL or JavaBeans. If it is indexable then this will return whether it is a JavaBeans indexed property, conforming to the indexed property patterns (returns INDEXED_PROPERTY_INT) or if it conforms to the OGNL arbitrary object indexable (returns INDEXED_PROPERTY_OBJECT).
This is a highly specialized map for storing values keyed by Type objects.

members.member:
This exception is thrown when parse errors are encountered. You can explicitly create objects of this exception type by calling the method generateParseException in the generated parser.
You can modify this class to customize your error reporting mechanisms so long as you retain the public fields.

The following constructors are for use by you for whatever purpose you can think of. Constructing the exception in this manner makes the exception behave in the normal way - i.e., as documented in the class "Exception". The fields "errorToken", "expectedTokenSequences", and "tokenImage" do not contain relevant information. The JavaCC generated code does not use these constructors.
This variable determines which constructor was used to create this object and thereby affects the semantics of the "getMessage" method (see below).
This is the last token that has been consumed successfully. If this object has been created due to a parse error, the token followng this token will (therefore) be the first error token.
Each entry in this array is an array of integers. Each array of integers represents a sequence of tokens (by their ordinal values) that is expected at this point of the parse.
This is a reference to the "tokenImage" array of the generated parser within which the parse error occurred. This array is defined in the generated ...Constants interface.

This method has the standard behavior when this object has been created using the standard constructors. Otherwise, it uses "currentToken" and "expectedTokenSequences" to generate a parse error message and returns it. If this object has been created due to a parse error, and you do not catch it (it gets thrown from the parser), then this method is called during the printing of the stack trace, and hence the correct error message gets displayed.
The end of line string for this machine.
Used to convert raw characters to their escaped version when these raw version cannot be used as part of an ASCII string literal.
OgnlParser is a JavaCC parser class; it translates OGNL expressions into abstract syntax trees (ASTs) that can then be interpreted by the getValue and setValue methods.
This is the top-level construct of OGNL.
Apply an expression to all elements of a collection, creating a new collection as the result.
Apply a bool expression to all elements of a collection, creating a new collection containing those elements for which the expression returned true.
Apply a bool expression to all elements of a collection, creating a new collection containing those elements for the first element for which the expression returned true.
Apply a bool expression to all elements of a collection, creating a new collection containing those elements for the first element for which the expression returned true.
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)

PropertyDescriptor subclass that describes an indexed set of read/write methods to get a property. Unlike IndexedPropertyDescriptor this allows the "key" to be an arbitrary object rather than just an int.
Consequently it does not have a "readMethod" or "writeMethod" because it only expects a pattern like:
public void setProperty(KeyType, ValueType); public ValueType getProperty(KeyType);
and does not require the methods that access it as an array. OGNL can get away with this without losing functionality because if the object does expose the properties they are most probably in a IDictionary and that case is handled by the normal OGNL property accessors. For example, if an object were to have methods that accessed and "attributes" property it would be natural to index them by string rather than by integer and expose the attributes as a map with a different property name:
public void setAttribute(string name, object value); public object getAttribute(string name); public IDictionary getAttributes();
Note that the index get/set is called get/set Attribute whereas the collection getter is called Attributes. This case is handled unambiguously by the OGNL property accessors because the set/getAttribute methods are detected by this object and the "attributes" case is handled by the MapPropertyAccessor. Therefore OGNL expressions calling this code would be handled in the following way:
OGNL Expression Handling
attribute["name"] Handled by an index getter, like getAttribute(string).
attribute["name"] = value Handled by an index setter, like setAttribute(string, object).
attributes["name"] Handled by MapPropertyAccessor via a IDictionary.get(). This will not go through the index get accessor.
attributes["name"] = value Handled by MapPropertyAccessor via a IDictionary.put(). This will not go through the index set accessor.
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)

member.name: T:ognl.IntHashMap
member.summary: A IDictionary that uses ints as the keys.

remarks.para: Use just like any java.util.IDictionary, except that the keys must be ints. This is much faster than creating a new Integer for each access.
For non-IDictionary access (faster) use the put(int, object) method.
This class : IDictionary for convenience, but this is not the most efficient usage.

members.member:
This class has predefined instances that stand for OGNL's special "dynamic subscripts" for getting at the first, middle, or last elements of a list.
In OGNL expressions, these subscripts look like special kinds of array indexes:
[^]means the first element
[$]means the last
[|]means the middle
[*]means the whole list
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)

member.name: F:ognl.DynamicSubscript.FIRST
member.summary: First element: ^.

member.name: F:ognl.DynamicSubscript.MID
member.summary: Middle element: |.

member.name: F:ognl.DynamicSubscript.LAST
member.summary: Last element: $.

member.name: F:ognl.DynamicSubscript.ALL
member.summary: All Element: *.

member.name: M:ognl.DynamicSubscript.getFlag
member.summary: Gets dynamic subscript flag.

member.name: T:ognl.IntrospectionException
member.summary: Copy from java.beans Thrown when an exception happens during Introspection.
member.remarks: Typical causes include not being able to map a string class name to a Class object, not being able to resolve a string method name, or specifying a method name that has the wrong type signature for its intended use.

member.name: M:ognl.IntrospectionException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs an IntrospectionException with a detailed message.
member.param: Descriptive message

members.member: Describes the input token stream.
An integer that describes the kind of this token. This numbering system is determined by JavaCCParser, and a table of these numbers is stored in the file ...Constants.java.
beginLine and beginColumn describe the position of the first character of this token; endLine and endColumn describe the position of the last character of this token.
beginLine and beginColumn describe the position of the first character of this token; endLine and endColumn describe the position of the last character of this token.
beginLine and beginColumn describe the position of the first character of this token; endLine and endColumn describe the position of the last character of this token.
beginLine and beginColumn describe the position of the first character of this token; endLine and endColumn describe the position of the last character of this token.
The string image of the token.

A reference to the next regular (non-special) token from the input stream. If this is the last token from the input stream, or if the token manager has not read tokens beyond this one, this field is set to null. This is true only if this token is also a regular token. Otherwise, see below for a description of the contents of this field.

This field is used to access special tokens that occur prior to this token, but after the immediately preceding regular (non-special) token. If there are no such special tokens, this field is set to null. When there are more than one such special token, this field refers to the last of these special tokens, which in turn refers to the next previous special token through its specialToken field, and so on until the first special token (whose specialToken field is null). The next fields of special tokens refer to other special tokens that immediately follow it (without an intervening regular token). If there is no such token, this field is null.
Returns the image.
@author Luke Blanshard (blanshlu@netscape.net) @author Drew Davidson (drew@ognl.org)
